Outline of Operations

Source: BRIGHTON.md

Summary of progress made and current goals as of May 13, 2023.

Next Steps

We decided that the next thing to do would be to document what already exists. This way we can wrap our heads around where we left off.

I also need to teach Danny the process of using examling, from installation to exporting.

The programmer in me would really like to thoroughly test what has been written so far. This means creating some more substantial tests that account for edge cases and running them all. My instinct is to make things that I know will work with the code I’ve written, so perhaps I’ll get some good tests when Danny starts writing questions.

The UX designer in me also wants to see what Danny creates without my input. How can I make the package more inuitive?

In testing, I could also try to solve some of the GitHub issues.

Installation Process

This package can be installed using devtools.install_github. What requirements are there for a package that can be installed in this way?

Documentation

Currently, many of the functions are documented in this README.md file. The plan is to create more formal documentation soon, integrated with the package itself. We need a few example packages to imitate in order to ensure that the documentation looks professional and correct.

As of the meeting on May 11, 2023, we plan to use pkgdown to create our documentation. https://pkgdown.r-lib.org/articles/pkgdown.html

The goal of pkgdown is to make it easy to make an elegant and useful package website with a minimum of work. You can get a basic website up and running in just a couple of minutes:

# Run once to configure package to use pkgdown
usethis::use_pkgdown()
# Run to build the website
pkgdown::build_site()

Logging

As of November 30, 2022, we are using the logr package to log all of the actions that take place when generating .Rmd files or whatever other process the user is performing.

High Priority * Date (automatically generated by logr) * Number of each type of question * Final count * URL to imported Google Sheets document * “Quick summary” of each question, by ID * How many dynamic versions

Lower Priority * Location of temporary .xlsx file from Google Sheets

Importing

A lot of the importing stuff has already been written and decently documented. We still need to write step-by-step instructions for starting with a spreadsheet and ending up with a folder of .Rmd files. I also need to write some exact requirements and restrictions, like what is not allowed for csv headers.

We can currently import from… * Dataframes * .csv files * .xslx files * Google Sheets

We’d like to import from… * Canvas * QTI/rtf

Canvas

The big thing with importing from and exporting to Canvas was that it was frustrating. We had some of the original creators of the exams package go in and try to figure some things out, with pretty minimal success.

In order to test out our package’s interactions with Canvas in the future, we can use the testing Canvas class, which Danny and I are both “TA”s for.

IDs

Identifiers are the file names under which generated .Rmd files are saved, in csv2rmd.r.

Currently, identifiers are generated using create_id(), which randomly generates a number and attaches it to the given category and subcategory. As unlikely as it may be, it is entirely possible that this function will generate the same ID for two distinct questions that have the same category and subcategory.

The current plan to solve this is listed in Todoist at https://todoist.com/app/search/id/task/6034389990.

If we can pull from all saved questions so far, then we can ensure that the unique ID is, in fact, unique.

This is also listed as an issue on Github at https://github.com/examLing/examling/issues/2.

Ids should be created using the classroom environment to ensure they are unique without having, like, 7-digit long identifying numbers.

Once there is an established location to save all .Rmd files, we can also search through these .Rmd files to ensure that we don’t repeat an ID. This is going to require a little more thought so we can distinguish between creating a new question and replacing an old one. A potential solution is to stop generating IDs and just have the user provide them instead, giving informative warnings or errors when duplicates are found.
